author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Peter S. Fischer, Who Helped Create ‘Murder, She Wrote,’ Dies at 88
description: He spent many years as a writer and producer of the hit mystery series starring Angela Lansbury. He later wrote his own mystery novels, set in Hollywood.
content: Peter S. Fischer, a creator, writer and producer of “Murder, She Wrote,” the long-running television series that starred Angela Lansbury as a mystery novelist and amateur sleuth, died on Oct. 30 in Pacific Grove, Calif. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Violence by West Bank Settlers Cannot Be Ignored
description: The Palestinians there whom I spoke to by telephone said people were aware of how terrible the consequences of an uprising would be.
content: After the thousands of Israelis killed on Oct. 7, and the thousands more Palestinians in Gaza killed in the war against Hamas, it may appear unseemly to focus on the relatively small and sadly familiar clashes between settlers and Palestinians in the West Bank. But it would be a mistake to overlook the danger of the escalation in settler violence over the past month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Johnson Pitches Bill to Avert Government Shutdown That Faces an Uncertain Fate
description: The measure would extend funding for some agencies through late January, and for others until early February. It omits funding for Ukraine or Israel.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson on Saturday pitched House Republicans on a convoluted plan to avert a government shutdown at the end of next week, proposing a bill that would temporarily extend funding for some federal agencies until late January and for others through early February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Surman and Vivian Nereim
title: Iran’s president visits Saudi Arabia for the first time since the two mended ties.
description: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran arrived in Saudi Arabia on Saturday for a summit on the war in Gaza, his first visit since the regional rivals agreed early this year to restore diplomatic ties after years of hostility.
content: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran arrived in Saudi Arabia on Saturday for a summit on the war in Gaza, his first visit since the regional rivals agreed early this year to restore diplomatic ties after years of hostility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Karen Davis, Who Battled for the Rights of Birds, Dies at 79
description: A fierce campaigner, Ms. Davis expanded the reach of the animal rights movement by advocating for chickens, turkeys and other farmyard fowl.
content: Karen Davis, an animal-rights activist who led campaigns to recognize the dignity of chickens, turkeys and other farmyard fowl — and whose fervor was such that she compared the industrial slaughter of poultry to the Holocaust — died on Nov. 4 at her sanctuary for rescued chickens in Machipongo, Va. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Padnani
title: The Lives Who Were Overlooked
description: The editor who created the “Overlooked” obituary series at The New York Times talks about the upcoming book compilation.
content: [This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: ‘We Cannot Kill Our Way Out of This Endeavor’
description: The United States has leverage as Israel’s most important ally and diplomatic protector. It needs to use it to end this war.
content: With the Middle East spiraling in the wrong direction, with too many fresh graves in Israel and Palestine alike, with children maimed and killed in Gaza in staggering numbers, with anger and bigotry spinning away to poison hearts around the world, the last, best hope may be President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Two Young Democratic Stars Collide Over Israel and Their Party’s Future
description: Representing neighboring districts in the Bronx, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Ritchie Torres have staked sharply divergent positions on the Israel-Hamas war.
content: They are among the brightest political stars rising from New York. They were born just months apart, 40 years after the founding of Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Sweeping Raids, Giant Camps and Mass Deportations: Inside Trump’s 2025 Immigration Plans
description: If he regains power, Donald Trump wants not only to revive some of the immigration policies criticized as draconian during his presidency, but expand and toughen them.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump is planning an extreme expansion of his first-term crackdown on immigration if he returns to power in 2025 — including preparing to round up undocumented people already in the United States on a vast scale and detain them in sprawling camps while they wait to be expelled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Wegovy Is Shown to Reduce Risk of Heart Attacks and Strokes in Some Patients
description: The results of a large clinical trial suggest the obesity medication could also change the landscape of cardiovascular care.
content: A pivotal new study suggests that the weight loss drug Wegovy cut the risk of heart attack, stroke or death from cardiovascular issues by 20 percent among overweight or obese people with heart disease — a striking benefit that could change the standard of care for these patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Louie Sussman
title: Why Aren’t More People Getting Married? Ask Women What Dating Is Like.
description: Harping on people to get married from up in the ivory tower fails to engage with reality of life in the dating trenches.
content: Sarah Camino had been in a relationship for two years when she found out she was pregnant. The father, whom she met while they were both working at a restaurant in Times Square, was initially excited. But he had been using drugs lately, and had been fired from his last four jobs; when she ventured that she was scared she might wind up raising the child alone, he got defensive and walked out. She and her daughter now live in Florida with her parents, and he is not a part of their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Asks Judge to Televise Federal Election Trial
description: The request to Judge Tanya Chutkan was short on legal arguments and long on bluster, and it faces an uphill battle as federal courts generally prohibit cameras.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump have told a judge that she should permit his trial on federal charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election to be televised live from the courtroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner
title: ‘The Climate’s No Good’: The Hunt for White Truffles Gets Pricier
description: Climate change in Italy has come for one of the world’s most sought-after delicacies. Foodies will probably see the impact when the check comes.
content: Primo and Scilla led the way deeper into the woods near Amandola, in central Italy. Across a gurgling brook, up a muddy slope, over mossy tree limbs, through a tangle of brambles and vines, the dogs covered acres of terrain. For nearly three hours, their olfactory senses were on high alert for white truffles, a delicacy with soaring prices, in large part because they are under extreme threat by climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Gulshan Khan
title: One Year in the Infuriating and Humiliating Search for a Job in South Africa
description: Portia Stafford has a high school diploma in hospitality and three certificates from job training programs. She is among a generation of ambitious Africans who spend their days chasing an elusive opening.
content: This is a part of a series on how Africa’s youth boom is changing the continent, and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Nov. 4-10
description: A European stroll might have helped you find this week’s hardest word.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Hear the Dance: Audio Description Comes of Age
description: Recent experiments in describing dance, like the film “Telephone,” approach it not just as an accessibility service but as a space for artistic exploration.
content: The dancer Krishna Washburn remembers attending a performance years ago by a well-known modern dance company at a large New York City theater. Washburn, who is blind, opted to experience the show with audio description: in this case, a track that narrated the dance as it was happening, delivered through a headset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nia Decaille
title: Doechii Stays Balanced With 24-Hour Spas and a Good Girls Night
description: This 25-year-old rapper is ready for a “new era” inspired by movies and theater. But first: a tour with Doja Cat. Here’s what keeps her on track.
content: Before the 25-year-old rapper and singer Doechii began opening for Doja Cat on the Scarlet Tour last month, she had a high-profile warm-up gig in Los Angeles, performing before Beyoncé on her Renaissance World Tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Launches Missile at Kyiv for First Time in Weeks, Ukraine Says
description: The attack was part of an overnight barrage that suggested Moscow was testing air defenses before another potential winter campaign against Ukraine’s energy infrastructure.
content: Ukraine’s military said on Saturday that it had shot down a Russian ballistic missile hurtling toward Kyiv, the first such attack on the capital in weeks, while cities across the country were targeted by a Russian air barrage that damaged several buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Hollywood Actors to Start Voting Tuesday on Contract Deal
description: The SAG-AFTRA board voted on Friday to send the agreement with studios to its members for a ratification process that will end in early December.
content: The union that represents movie and television actors said on Friday that its 76-member national board had voted with 86 percent support to send a tentative contract with studios to members for ratification.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: A Black Woman’s Rise in Architecture Shows How Far Is Left to Go
description: They have worked for decades to make their way in a profession that remains overwhelmingly white and male, but there are signs of change.
content: When Kimberly Dowdell becomes president of the American Institute of Architects next month, her ascent will be noteworthy. Ms. Dowdell, an architect in a profession that is overwhelmingly white and male, is a Black woman, the first to fill the post in the group’s 166-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Two Stories That Unfold Through Letters
description: An editor recommends “84, Charing Cross Road” and “The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society.”
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dara Mathis
title: Three Days That Changed the Thinking About Black Women’s Health
description: Forty years ago, Black women convened to discuss how race affected their health. They helped reimagine what medical care could look like.
content: On June 24, 1983, Byllye Avery welcomed busloads of Black women to the campus of Spelman College in Atlanta. She was in a state of disbelief. The women had traveled from Mississippi, New York, Pennsylvania — even as far away as California — for a three-day event billed as the First National Conference on Black Women’s Health Issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Should Joe Manchin Run for President?
description: If current polling holds, it’s not running an alternative to Biden that seems most likely to put Trump back in the presidency.
content: In the emotional life of the liberal mediasphere, there was so little space between the release of the New York Times/Siena poll showing President Biden losing to Donald Trump handily across a range of swing states (doom! doom!) and the Democratic overperformance in Tuesday’s elections (sweet relief!) that one of the striking features of the polling passed with relatively little comment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Ewing
title: Portraits From a Photo Shoot Far, Far Away
description: For an article about people who plan to send their remains to space, The New York Times Magazine arranged a remote-photography process. The sessions captured an astral mood.
content: While some people look up into the night sky and wonder what’s out there, Guy Pignolet, an 81-year-old space educator, can be confident that he will one day be part of the answer. After he dies, Mr. Pignolet plans to have his ashes launched into space.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Switzerland, Buying a Home Is Out of Reach
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 12, 2023.
content: “It’s beyond luxury. Two kids, a house, a garden, two cars — I don’t know anybody who has that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: The Only People Who Understand What a Caregiver Goes Through
description: Mentoring programs bring together those just starting to care for family members with dementia and those who have been coping for some time.
content: On Thursday mornings, Julia Sadtler and Debora Dunbar log onto Zoom to talk about caring for their husbands with Alzheimer’s disease, in hourlong conversations that are usually informative, sometimes emotional and always supportive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Storm Warning
description: Blake Slonecker delivers a relaxing but cerebral themeless.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle has a little something for the neophyte, and a little something for the grizzled vet. Anyone interested in a juicy solve that’s vibrant and likely to build your confidence rather than tear it to shreds? Well, walk this way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Millet
title: Florida Man Chases Poachers
description: In “Gator Country,” Rebecca Renner goes beyond the stereotypes to pay tribute to her beloved Everglades.
content: The journalist Rebecca Renner still lives in Central Florida, where she grew up playing in a swamp near her house and had her first close encounter with a full-size alligator at age 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Friend of the High Line Spends His Sundays
description: Alan van Capelle said he was “living the dream” with his husband and two children, a life he once thought was out of reach for someone like him.
content: Alan van Capelle spends a lot of time trying to foster equality and a sense of belonging as the executive director of Friends of the High Line, the nonprofit that oversees the park’s operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Agrawal
title: They Arrived Homeless. Now They’re Helping Others Make New York Home.
description: At a makeshift welcome center in the Lower East Side, those who came before help those who are new, and a community begins to grow.
content: The migrants started lining up by dawn. After trekking to New York from across Latin America, young people and families had made their way to an elementary school on the Lower East Side to be greeted, in Spanish, by immigrants who had come before them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis, Stephanie Saul, Nicholas Fandos and Alan Blinder
title: Harvard, Columbia and Penn Pledge to Fight Antisemitism on Campus
description: The universities are trying to address criticism by banning pro-Palestinian student groups, condemning slogans and starting task forces to address antisemitism.
content: Over the last month, university presidents have been battered by a vocal cohort of alumni and faculty members who have accused them of not being strong enough in their denunciations of antisemitism in the wake of the Hamas attack on Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Mint, the Budgeting App, Is Going Away. Here Are Some Alternatives.
description: Finding a money app that works best for you requires personal testing. We asked popular competitors to Mint why you should try their offerings.
content: The demise of Mint, the beloved budgeting app, has caused its millions of users to consider alternatives. That makes it as good a time as any for everyone to consider a money management tool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: When Aviation Was More Than the News
description: The Times didn’t just cover the pioneering aviators of the early 20th century. It sponsored their flights.
content: In charting the flight of the battery-powered CX300 aircraft recently, The New York Times was back where it has spent a lot of time over the last 120 years: in the clouds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: For Both Trudeau and Biden, Polls Suggest an Uphill Political Path
description: The economy, and particularly inflation, has soured voters on both leaders, polls indicate, though well in advance of upcoming votes.
content: When Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and President Biden next meet, they will have something to commiserate over: their dismal standings in polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ahmed Al Omran and Yara Bayoumy
title: Iran and Saudi Arabia, Regional Rivals, Call for Gaza Cease-Fire
description: The leaders of both Islamic countries appeared to put aside their historical animosities at a summit to present a united stand against Israel’s bombardment of the strip after Hamas’s attack.
content: The leaders of Iran and Saudi Arabia, regional rivals who restored diplomatic ties this year, met in Riyadh on Saturday at a summit where they called for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza and unconditional delivery of humanitarian aid to the enclave, which Israeli forces have besieged since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: They Wanted to Get Sober. They Got a Nightmare Instead.
description: Arizona spent $1 billion on addiction treatment, much of it fraudulent, officials said. Scores of Native Americans who sought help are still struggling with untreated addiction — and some died in rehab.
content: The white vans were the first thing people noticed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: No, 11,200 Climate Refugees Aren’t Heading to Australia
description: Low-lying Tuvalu has reached a deal with its large Pacific neighbor to address the challenge of rising oceans, but it is not planning to pack up and go.
content: The Pacific island nation of Tuvalu once comprised 11 islands. It is now down to nine flecks of land totaling less than 10 square miles, which, like their lost siblings before them, risk gradually being eaten away by the rising tides of the world’s warming oceans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Bernhard Warner
title: Sam Bankman-Fried Could Get 100 Years in Prison. What Is Fair?
description: The founder of the failed FTX cryptocurrency exchange was found guilty of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy.
content: After a monthlong trial and about four hours of deliberation, a jury convicted the FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy last week. He had been accused of stealing billions of dollars from his cryptocurrency exchange’s customers and investors, funneling the money into his investments and extravagant spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Amit Elkayam
title: They Ran Into a Bomb Shelter for Safety. Instead, They Were Slaughtered.
description: Hamas’s assault on southern Israel began with a barrage of rockets, sending scores of people into roadside refuges. Then gunmen came to hunt them.
content: Nearly 30 young people took refuge inside a grimy bunker on the morning of Oct. 7, hoping the reinforced-concrete shelter near the border with Gaza would fulfill its promise of protection.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tough Decisions About Dementia and End-of-Life Care
description: Readers discuss Sandeep Jauhar’s guest essay about dementia and advance directives.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Family in ‘Take Care of Maya’ Documentary Is Awarded $261 Million
description: A jury found that a Florida hospital, which had suspected child abuse, was liable for charges including medical negligence and false imprisonment in its treatment of Maya Kowalski in 2016.
content: A jury in Florida ordered a hospital to pay $261 million in damages to a family after the parents were accused of abusing their daughter and barred from seeing her during months of treatment. Their story was chronicled in the Netflix documentary “Take Care of Maya.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: How Millions of Borrowers Got $127 Billion in Student Loans Canceled
description: The Biden administration may have been blocked from canceling debt for tens of millions of borrowers by the Supreme Court, but it has still managed to eliminate billions in education debt.
content: When the Supreme Court struck down President Biden’s $400 billion plan to forgive up to $20,000 in federal student loan debt for 43 million borrowers, the prospect of substantive debt relief appeared to vanish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Holsinger
title: The Members of This ‘Manuscripts Club’ Were Obsessed With Medieval Books
description: The bibliophiles in Christopher de Hamel’s lavishly illustrated book ensured the survival of medieval texts over centuries.
content: A harrowing passage in Hilary Mantel’s “Wolf Hall” describes the ransacking of Cardinal Wolsey’s house in 1529 by the Dukes of Norfolk and Sussex, a pillage that included recklessly emptying Wolsey’s chests of their medieval books: “The texts are heavy to hold in the arms, and awkward as if they breathed; their pages are made of slunk vellum from stillborn calves, reveined by the illuminator in tints of lapis and leaf-green.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Ohio Voted to Protect Abortion Rights. Could Florida Be Next?
description: A coalition of groups collecting petition signatures for a ballot protecting abortion rights says its fund-raising got a boost after the Ohio results.
content: Since the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year, campaigns to protect abortion rights have galvanized voters in state after state. It has become Democrats’ most successful issue ahead of an uncertain 2024 election cycle — and their biggest hope, especially after voters in Ohio approved on Tuesday a measure to enshrine abortion rights in the State Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Burleigh
title: Ivanka Trump, Witness for the Prosecution
description: While the country debates Donald Trump’s real net worth, should we also ask if his daughter was anything more than window dressing for him?
content: It’s been almost three years since, on Jan. 6, 2021, Ivanka Trump, swaddled in a black coat, stood beside her father inside a tent on the Ellipse in Washington, D.C. Until her walk up the steps of the New York State Supreme Courthouse on Wednesday, that was one of her last public family appearances in an official capacity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Tanner
title: A Gamy Picaresque for the Age of the Notes-App Apology
description: In Lexi Freiman’s “The Book of Ayn,” a canceled novelist drifts from New York parties to L.A. parties to a commune in Greece, spreading the gospel of Ayn Rand.
content: A bucket of moldy jam stored in the walk-in storage closet of an L.A. cafe; famous men masturbating in front of young women; misappropriated campaign funds: Such real-life cancellation plots provide the unspoken backdrop to Lexi Freiman’s angular, careening latest, “The Book of Ayn,” which charts a writer’s undoing after she publishes an opioid crisis satire, written from a rent-free pied-à-terre with a view of the Empire State Building. This is a gamy picaresque for the age of the notes-app apology: a cutting novel of ego and its death, Freudian yearning, Randian Hollywood, scatological epiphany and the vileness of the pursuit of a career in letters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Landlord Disappeared With the Security Deposit. How Do I Get It Back?
description: State law requires landlords to return security deposits within 14 days.
content: Q: After selling our apartment in Brooklyn, my family and I rented for 14 months from an owner in our building. We thought we had a good relationship with her and took excellent care of the apartment. But when we moved out, she returned only a small portion of our security deposit and said she was withholding the rest while she assessed some “questionable” issues. All were either her responsibility, like changing the locks, or the building’s. She never told us where the security deposit was being held, nor produced an invoice showing how the deposit was used to address any issues. We’ve heard nothing since August, despite our attempts to reach her. We are now living overseas and are out thousands of dollars. What can we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Elemia
title: How a Decaying Warship Beached on a Tiny Shoal Provoked China’s Ire
description: After multiple maritime clashes, the Philippines invited journalists on a mission to resupply the Sierra Madre. A reporter for The Times was given rare access.
content: For more than two decades, it has been an unlikely flashpoint in the South China Sea: a rusty, World War II-era ship beached on a tiny reef that has become a symbol of Philippine resistance against Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia, Stephen Castle and Esther Bintliff
title: Major Pro-Palestinian March Staged in London as Police Ramp Up Security
description: The gathering drew an estimated 300,000 people, the police said, making it one of the largest protests in Britain in recent years. Before it began, far-right demonstrators scuffled with officers.
content: Hundreds of thousands of people marched through central London in a huge pro-Palestinian demonstration on Saturday, a tense day in which the police battled with a small right-wing group to keep order on some city streets.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 11, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 11, 2023.
content: An article on Page 14 this weekend about the U.S. Space Force misspelled the surname of a member of the U.S. Space Force. He is Lt. Col. Galen Thorp, not Thorpe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall, Amanda Taub, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Andrea Bruce
title: Chapter 4: The Wedding
description: It was the moment two families had long waited for. But Arti feared it could be the end of her dreams for a career.
content: For Indian families, a modest wedding is an oxymoron. No matter how meager a household’s earnings, no expense can be spared. It was no different for Arti Kumari’s parents, despite their limited means as an NGO worker and a subsistence farmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
title: Russia Glorifies Its World War II Dead. He Tries to Give Them Decent Burials.
description: Konstantin Dobrovolsky searches for the remains of soldiers left to rot on the battlefield almost 80 years ago. Then he had to bury his own son, who fought in a war he despises.
content: The skeletons are never far away from Konstantin A. Dobrovolsky. Sometimes he sleeps above them in a tiny olive-green trailer in the woods. The people they might once have been appear in his dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Overwhelmed With Writing Your Vows? A Professional Wordsmith Could Help.
description: In recent years, social media has helped increase demand in this new wedding vendor category. “Vows have gone viral,” one expert said, “and there’s greater attention to the moments that go wrong.”
content: The 200 guests at Rachel Mumford’s backyard wedding in Malibu, Calif., were suddenly on their feet, clapping, giving her an unexpected ovation. Forty-eight hours earlier, she probably wouldn’t have felt as calm or confident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: ‘These babies, these ladies, these old people’: Macron mourns civilian deaths and urges an Israeli cease-fire.
description: Against a backdrop of mounting international outrage over civilian casualties as Israel wages war on Hamas, President Emmanuel Macron of France on Friday called on Israel to stop the killing in Gaza.
content: Against a backdrop of mounting international outrage over civilian casualties as Israel wages war on Hamas, President Emmanuel Macron of France on Friday called on Israel to stop the killing in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: A Pond in Hawaii Turned Pink, Raising an Environmental Red Flag
description: Dry conditions and high salt levels in the water allowed for halobacteria to thrive, turning a pond bubble-gum pink.
content: A pond in Hawaii became a social media spectacle this week after turning bubble-gum pink. However, experts said the new hue was not just a photo opportunity but an indicator of environmental stress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandria Symonds
title: Inside Facebook’s Dangerous Battle Between Integrity and Engagement
description: Jeff Horwitz’s “Broken Code” draws on 25,000 pages of internal documents to reveal the company’s tumultuous inner workings — and their devastating impact on humanity.
content: In a welcome departure from the subgenre of stories about Facebook, Jeff Horwitz’s “Broken Code” doesn’t open in a Harvard dorm room. Expanding on the revelations of his blockbuster “Facebook Files” series of articles in The Wall Street Journal, the book focuses squarely on the past decade. It begins when Facebook is already a global behemoth with a user count in the billions — and a company ethos that has yet to account for its capacity to effect enormous social and political change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: The Pies Are Here
description: Caramel apple pie, pumpkin pie with pepitas, pecan slab pie and lemon pudding pie with honey and ginger. Oh, and a cranberry cheesecake tart.
content: The pies are here! Four words, so much joy (and butter). This year’s batch of beauties from Claire Saffitz (above) is particularly lovely, both in the eating and the sharing: pumpkin pie with pepitas, lemon cream pie with honey and ginger, caramel apple pie, pecan slab pie and a cranberry cheesecake tart. She also has a clever new pie dough recipe, in case you can’t pull yourself or your family from one of our many other fantastic Thanksgiving pie recipes. Push up those sleeves, cube that butter and flour that bench: It’s pie time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Icelandic Town Evacuated as Earthquakes Portend Volcanic Eruption
description: Officials said that “the likelihood of a volcanic eruption” in the near future was “considerable” in Grindavik, home to about 4,000 people.
content: Icelandic authorities declared a state of emergency and evacuated a town of about 4,000 people on Saturday after hundreds of earthquakes were detected overnight, signaling an increased likelihood of a volcano erupting in the country’s southwestern Reykjanes Peninsula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Our Merch, Ourselves
description: What do the bands and brands whose merchandise we buy say about who we are and what we value?
content: If you want to recreate the 1960s winged eyeliner that Cailee Spaeny wears in “Priscilla,” you’ll have to do so without the aid of the limited-edition makeup kit produced by the film’s studio, A24. It’s sold out. Ditto the dark gray sweatshirt with tonal “Priscilla” embroidery across the front. You can, however, still purchase a baby-doll T-shirt bedizened with the film’s title in rhinestones. And the heart-shaped locket by the jewelry designer J. Hannah, inspired by the one Priscilla wears in the movie, which was in turn inspired by one Priscilla Presley actually wore, is still available, in sterling silver ($400) or 14-karat gold ($1,280).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim, Ameera Harouda and Alan Yuhas
title: Gaza Hospitals Near Collapse as Fighting Rages Nearby
description: Facing power outages and shortages of food, water and medical supplies, hospitals are struggling just to keep patients alive, Gazan health authorities say.
content: Operations at Gaza’s main hospital were showing signs of collapse on Saturday, with its director and the Gazan Health Ministry describing power outages, shortages of water and medicine and a crisis in treating seriously wounded patients and vulnerable children, while battles between Israeli troops and Hamas fighters raged ever closer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Right on the Money
description: Garrett Chalfin’s Sunday puzzle comes with a price.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Florida-Bound Plane Had Missing and Damaged Windowpanes After Takeoff
description: Passengers aboard the plane, which took off from London, told investigators that the cabin had seemed noisier and colder than they were used to.
content: A plane flying from London to Orlando, Fla., last month was forced to turn around because some windowpanes were missing or damaged, startling passengers who had reported hearing roaring sounds inside the cabin, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: Parents Are People
description: What happens when you realize the people in charge don’t have the answers.
content: What happens when you realize the people in charge don’t have the answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucinda Rogers
title: Drawings of a City Divided: New York Reacts to the Israel-Hamas War
description: To many New Yorkers, the war feels extremely close to home.
content: I started drawing New York over 30 years ago when I first arrived in the city as a visitor from London. Since then, I have witnessed the city as its architecture and population changed. I saw the city coping with loss and recorded scenes at ground zero in the months after the Sept. 11 attacks. And now I have seen the new trauma of a city divided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: David Ferry, Poet and Translator Who Won Acclaim Late in Life, Dies at 99
description: After nearly 40 years as a professor, he began a new career writing poems and translating classics. He won a National Book Award when he was 86.
content: David Ferry, a poet and translator whose direct, emotionally resonant work plumbing the chasms between the knowable and the unknowable won him broad praise and honors late in his career, including the National Book Award when he was 86, died on Sunday in Lexington, Mass. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou
title: Life in Gaza City: Privation, Rationing and Desperate Fear
description: Mohammad Matar, a civil engineer, and his family have remained in the city even as Israeli ground forces continue their relentless assault.
content: For years, Mohammad Matar worked on constructing pipelines that moved water across the Gaza Strip — from northern Beit Lahia to southern Rafah. Now, he can barely get access to water himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Louisiana Must Finalize New Voting Map by January, Federal Appeals Court Says
description: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit agreed with a lower-court ruling that the latest congressional map very likely diluted the power of Black voters.
content: A federal appeals court on Friday agreed with a lower-court ruling that Louisiana’s latest congressional map very likely violated the Voting Rights Act by diluting the power of Black voters, and ordered the state to finalize a new map by Jan. 15.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Lozada
title: A Trump-Biden Rematch Is the Election We Need
description: How else are we going to resolve the questions that hang over our democracy?
content: Joe Biden versus Donald Trump is not the choice America wants. But it is the choice we need to face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Jason Horowitz
title: Texas Bishop Loudly Critical of the Pope Is Removed
description: Bishop Joseph Strickland was a highly prominent figure among traditionalist American Catholics who see Pope Francis as too liberal.
content: Pope Francis fired on Saturday a bishop in Texas who was one of his loudest American critics within the Catholic Church, a highly rare dismissal that appeared to reflect the growing rift between the Vatican and a more conservative wing of the church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Right-Wing Counterprotesters Clash With Police in London
description: Dozens were arrested after skirmishes broke out between far-right demonstrators and the London police near a pro-Palestinian march that coincided with Armistice Day.
content: Dozens were arrested after skirmishes broke out between far-right demonstrators and the London police near a pro-Palestinian march that coincided with Armistice Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cassel, Ayman Abu Ramouz and Caroline Kim
title: They Left Gaza to Work in Israel. Now They’re Stranded.
description: Thousands of workers from Gaza have been trapped in the West Bank since the Hamas attacks on October 7. Their Israeli work permits have been canceled, and they’re deeply worried about their families back home.
content: Thousands of workers from Gaza have been trapped in the West Bank since the Hamas attacks on October 7. Their Israeli work permits have been canceled, and they’re deeply worried about their families back home.
source.name: The New York Times
